PSO Algorithm TheoryÂ¶

Understanding Swarm Intelligence and Optimization Principles

This guide explains the theoretical foundations of Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), from bio-inspired origins to convergence guarantees. Youâ€™ll learn why PSO works, how to tune parameters, and when to use PSO vs other optimizers.

Table of ContentsÂ¶

  • Swarm Intelligence Principles

  • PSO Convergence Theory

  • Parameter Selection Guidelines

  • Benchmark Comparisons

Swarm Intelligence PrinciplesÂ¶

Bio-Inspired OriginsÂ¶

PSO is inspired by social behavior of bird flocking and fish schooling:

Observation in Nature:

  • Birds find food sources efficiently without central coordination

  • Each bird adjusts based on:

    1. Its own best experience (cognitive component)

    2. The flockâ€™s best experience (social component)

Translation to Optimization:

  • Particles = candidate solutions

  • Position = solution in search space

  • Velocity = direction and speed of search

  • Best positions = best solutions found

The PSO AlgorithmÂ¶

Algorithm Overview:

flowchart TD
    INIT[Initialize Swarm<br/>Random positions & velocities] --> EVAL1[Evaluate Fitness<br/>Run simulations]
    EVAL1 --> UPDATE_P[Update Personal Best<br/>páµ¢ = best position for each particle]
    UPDATE_P --> UPDATE_G[Update Global Best<br/>g = best position overall]

    UPDATE_G --> UPDATE_V[Update Velocities<br/>váµ¢ = wÂ·váµ¢ + câ‚Â·râ‚Â·(páµ¢-xáµ¢) + câ‚‚Â·râ‚‚Â·(g-xáµ¢)]
    UPDATE_V --> UPDATE_X[Update Positions<br/>xáµ¢ = xáµ¢ + váµ¢]

    UPDATE_X --> CHECK{Converged?<br/>(Max iterations<br/>or stagnation)}
    CHECK -->|No| EVAL2[Evaluate Fitness]
    EVAL2 --> UPDATE_P

    CHECK -->|Yes| DONE[Return Global Best<br/>Optimized gains]

    style INIT fill:#ccccff
    style DONE fill:#ccffcc

Each particle i has:

  • Position: xáµ¢(t) (current solution)

  • Velocity: váµ¢(t) (search direction)

  • Personal best: páµ¢ (best position found by particle i)

  • Global best: g (best position found by entire swarm)

Update Equations:

váµ¢(t+1) = wÂ·váµ¢(t) + câ‚Â·râ‚Â·(páµ¢ - xáµ¢(t)) + câ‚‚Â·râ‚‚Â·(g - xáµ¢(t))
xáµ¢(t+1) = xáµ¢(t) + váµ¢(t+1)

Where:

  • w: Inertia weight (momentum)

  • câ‚: Cognitive coefficient (self-confidence)

  • câ‚‚: Social coefficient (swarm confidence)

  • râ‚, râ‚‚: Random numbers in [0,1] (stochastic exploration)

Intuitive Meaning:

  • wÂ·váµ¢(t): Keep moving in current direction (exploration)

  • câ‚Â·râ‚Â·(páµ¢ - xáµ¢): Move toward own best (personal experience)

  • câ‚‚Â·râ‚‚Â·(g - xáµ¢): Move toward swarm best (social learning)

Velocity Update Visualization:

flowchart TD
    V_OLD["váµ¢(t)<br/>(Current Velocity)"] --> INERTIA["wÂ·váµ¢(t)<br/>Inertia Component"]
    X["xáµ¢(t)<br/>(Current Position)"] --> COGNITIVE["câ‚Â·râ‚Â·(páµ¢ - xáµ¢)<br/>Cognitive Pull"]
    X --> SOCIAL["câ‚‚Â·râ‚‚Â·(g - xáµ¢)<br/>Social Pull"]

    PBEST["páµ¢<br/>(Personal Best)"] --> COGNITIVE
    GBEST["g<br/>(Global Best)"] --> SOCIAL

    INERTIA --> SUM["+"]
    COGNITIVE --> SUM
    SOCIAL --> SUM

    SUM --> V_NEW["váµ¢(t+1)<br/>(New Velocity)"]
    V_NEW --> X_NEW["xáµ¢(t+1) = xáµ¢(t) + váµ¢(t+1)<br/>(New Position)"]

    style INERTIA fill:#ccccff
    style COGNITIVE fill:#ccffcc
    style SOCIAL fill:#ffcccc
    style X_NEW fill:#ffffcc

Components:

  • ğŸ”µ Inertia: Momentum from previous motion

  • ğŸŸ¢ Cognitive: Attraction to personal best experience

  • ğŸ”´ Social: Attraction to swarmâ€™s collective best

  • ğŸŸ¡ Result: Balanced exploration and exploitation

Exploration vs ExploitationÂ¶

Exploration: Search broadly to find new regions

  • High inertia w â†’ more exploration

  • Randomness râ‚, râ‚‚ â†’ stochastic search

Exploitation: Search deeply in promising regions

  • High cognitive/social câ‚, câ‚‚ â†’ focus on best solutions

  • Decrease w over time â†’ transition to exploitation

Balanced Search:

Early iterations: High w (explore) + low câ‚,câ‚‚
Late iterations: Low w (exploit) + high câ‚,câ‚‚

Exploration vs Exploitation Balance:

graph LR
    subgraph "PSO Search Strategy"
        EARLY["Early Iterations<br/>High w (0.9)<br/>Spread particles"] -->|Time| MID["Middle Phase<br/>Moderate w (0.7)<br/>Focused search"]
        MID -->|Time| LATE["Late Iterations<br/>Low w (0.4)<br/>Converge to optimum"]

        style EARLY fill:#ffcccc
        style MID fill:#ffffcc
        style LATE fill:#ccffcc
    end

Phases:

  • ğŸ”´ Exploration (High w): Search broadly, discover promising regions

  • ğŸŸ¡ Transition (Medium w): Balance between search and convergence

  • ğŸŸ¢ Exploitation (Low w): Refine solution, converge to optimum

Global vs Local OptimaÂ¶

Multi-modal Functions: Multiple peaks (local optima)

PSO finds global optimum because:

  1. Swarm diversity: Particles spread across search space

  2. Information sharing: Global best guides swarm

  3. Stochastic search: Random components escape local traps

Risk of Premature Convergence:

  • All particles cluster at local optimum

  • Swarm loses diversity â†’ stuck

  • Solution: Maintain diversity (inertia decay, topology variants)

PSO Convergence TheoryÂ¶

Convergence GuaranteesÂ¶

Theorem (Simplified): Under certain conditions, PSO converges to global optimum:

Conditions:

  1. Bounded search space: x âˆˆ [x_min, x_max]

  2. Sufficient particles: N â‰¥ some threshold (problem-dependent)

  3. Appropriate parameters: w, câ‚, câ‚‚ in stable region

Convergence Rate:

  • Linear convergence for unimodal functions

  • Sublinear for multi-modal functions

  • Faster than random search, comparable to genetic algorithms

Velocity ClampingÂ¶

Problem: Velocities can grow unbounded â†’ particles leave search space

Solution: Clamp velocities

if |váµ¢| > v_max:
    váµ¢ = v_max Â· sign(váµ¢)

Guideline: v_max = 0.1 to 0.5 Ã— (x_max - x_min)

Effect on Convergence:

  • Too small v_max â†’ slow convergence (limited exploration)

  • Too large v_max â†’ oscillations (overshoot optima)

  • Optimal v_max â†’ smooth convergence

Constriction FactorÂ¶

Alternative to velocity clamping: Constriction coefficient Ï‡

Update Equation:

váµ¢(t+1) = Ï‡ Â· [váµ¢(t) + câ‚Â·râ‚Â·(páµ¢ - xáµ¢) + câ‚‚Â·râ‚‚Â·(g - xáµ¢)]

Where:

Ï‡ = 2 / |2 - Ï† - âˆš(Ï†Â² - 4Ï†)|
Ï† = câ‚ + câ‚‚ > 4

Canonical Values:

câ‚ = câ‚‚ = 2.05
Ï† = 4.1
Ï‡ â‰ˆ 0.7298

Advantage: Guaranteed convergence (no velocity clamping needed)

Stagnation and Premature ConvergenceÂ¶

Stagnation: Particles stop improving

Causes:

  1. Swarm collapsed: All particles at same location

  2. Local optimum trap: Swarm stuck in basin of attraction

  3. Diversity loss: Velocities â†’ 0

Detection:

if std(positions) < threshold:
    stagnation = True

Solutions:

  1. Restart: Re-initialize particles

  2. Repulsion: Add repulsive forces between particles

  3. Topology: Use local best instead of global (preserve diversity)

Parameter Selection GuidelinesÂ¶

Swarm SizeÂ¶

Theory: Larger swarm â†’ better exploration, but more expensive

Guidelines:

N = 10 + 2âˆšD

Where D = problem dimensionality

For Controller Tuning:

  • Classical SMC (6 gains): N = 10 + 2âˆš6 â‰ˆ 15 particles

  • Adaptive SMC (5 gains): N = 10 + 2âˆš5 â‰ˆ 15 particles

  • Hybrid SMC (4 gains): N = 10 + 2âˆš4 â‰ˆ 14 particles

Practical Range: 20-50 particles for most problems

Iteration CountÂ¶

Theory: More iterations â†’ better convergence, but more time

Convergence Indicators:

  1. Fitness improvement < threshold (e.g., 0.1% over 10 iterations)

  2. Swarm diversity < threshold

  3. Maximum iterations reached

Guidelines:

Quick tuning: 50 iterations
Standard: 100 iterations
Thorough: 200+ iterations

For Controller Tuning:

  • Prototyping: 50 iterations (5-10 min)

  • Development: 100 iterations (10-20 min)

  • Publication: 200 iterations (20-40 min)

Inertia Weight StrategiesÂ¶

Constant Inertia: w = 0.7298 (constriction factor)

  • Simple, works for many problems

  • No adaptation to problem

Linearly Decreasing:

w(t) = w_max - (w_max - w_min) Â· t/T

  • w_max = 0.9 (initial exploration)

  • w_min = 0.4 (final exploitation)

  • T = max iterations

Adaptive: Adjust based on convergence

if improving:
    w = w_max (explore more)
else:
    w = w_min (exploit current region)

Cognitive/Social CoefficientsÂ¶

Classical Values: câ‚ = câ‚‚ = 2.05 (balanced)

Exploration-Heavy: câ‚ = 2.5, câ‚‚ = 1.5

  • Emphasize personal experience

  • Slower convergence, better global search

Exploitation-Heavy: câ‚ = 1.5, câ‚‚ = 2.5

  • Emphasize swarm best

  • Faster convergence, risk of local traps

Recommendation for Controller Tuning:

câ‚ = 1.49618  (cognitive)
câ‚‚ = 1.49618  (social)
w = 0.7298    (inertia)

Benchmark ComparisonsÂ¶

PSO vs Genetic Algorithms (GA)Â¶

Aspect

PSO

Genetic Algorithm

Inspiration

Swarm behavior

Evolution

Population

Continuous evolution

Generational

Operators

Velocity updates

Crossover, mutation

Convergence

Fast (few iterations)

Slower (many generations)

Parameters

3-4 (w, câ‚, câ‚‚, N)

Many (crossover rate, mutation, selection)

Tuning Difficulty

Easy

Harder

Best For

Continuous optimization

Discrete, combinatorial

For Controller Gain Tuning: PSO is generally better

  • Continuous search space (gain values)

  • Fewer parameters to tune

  • Faster convergence

Algorithm Comparison for SMC Tuning:

graph TD
    PROBLEM["Controller Gain Tuning<br/>(6-8 parameters)"] --> CHOICE{Problem<br/>Characteristics}

    CHOICE -->|Continuous<br/>Non-differentiable<br/>Multi-modal| PSO["PSO<br/>âœ“ Best choice<br/>Fast, robust"]
    CHOICE -->|Discrete<br/>Combinatorial| GA["Genetic Algorithm<br/>âœ“ Good for discrete<br/>Slower convergence"]
    CHOICE -->|Smooth<br/>Convex<br/>Gradient available| GRAD["Gradient Descent<br/>âœ“ Fast if convex<br/>Local optima risk"]

    PSO --> RESULT["Optimized SMC Gains<br/>(100-200 iterations)"]
    GA --> RESULT2["Optimized Gains<br/>(500+ generations)"]
    GRAD --> RESULT3["Local Optimum<br/>(Fast but risky)"]

    style PSO fill:#ccffcc
    style GA fill:#ffffcc
    style GRAD fill:#ffcccc

Recommendation: Use PSO for SMC gain tuning due to non-differentiable cost functions (sign, saturation) and multimodal landscapes.

PSO vs Gradient-Based MethodsÂ¶

Aspect

PSO

Gradient Methods

Requirements

Only function values

Gradient information

Derivative-Free

Yes

No

Global Search

Yes

No (local methods)

Convergence Speed

Moderate

Fast (if convex)

Multimodal Functions

Good

Poor (stuck in local)

Noise Tolerance

High

Low

When PSO Excels:

  1. Non-differentiable cost functions (e.g., thresholding, max operations)

  2. Multimodal landscapes (many local optima)

  3. Noisy evaluations (stochastic simulations)

  4. Black-box problems (no gradient available)

When Gradient Methods Excel:

  1. Smooth, convex functions (quadratic costs)

  2. High-dimensional problems (PSO struggles >100 dimensions)

  3. Gradient available (analytical or auto-diff)

PSO vs Random SearchÂ¶

Aspect

PSO

Random Search

Intelligence

Guided by best solutions

Purely random

Convergence

Faster (information sharing)

Slower

Parallelization

Moderate (some dependency)

Perfect (independent)

Simplicity

Moderate complexity

Very simple

Efficiency Comparison:

Random Search: O(NÂ²) samples to find optimum
PSO: O(NÂ·log N) samples (empirical)

For Controller Tuning: PSO is 10-100Ã— faster than random search

When PSO StrugglesÂ¶

High Dimensions (D > 100):

  • Curse of dimensionality

  • Swarm size grows: N âˆ âˆšD

  • Consider: CMA-ES, differential evolution

Discrete/Combinatorial Problems:

  • PSO designed for continuous

  • Consider: GA, simulated annealing

Tight Constraints:

  • PSO may violate constraints frequently

  • Consider: penalty methods or constraint-handling variants

Very Fast Evaluation (< 1ms):

  • PSO overhead dominates

  • Consider: Gradient methods (if differentiable)

SummaryÂ¶

Key Takeaways:

  1. PSO Principle: Particles balance personal experience and swarm knowledge

  2. Convergence: Guaranteed under proper parameter settings (constriction factor)

  3. Parameter Tuning: Use canonical values (w=0.73, câ‚=câ‚‚=1.5) or adapt inertia

  4. vs GA: Faster for continuous problems, easier to tune

  5. vs Gradient: Better for multimodal, non-differentiable, noisy problems

Best Practices for Controller Tuning:

N_particles = 30           # Sufficient for 4-6 gains
max_iters = 100            # Balance speed and quality
w = 0.7298                 # Constriction factor
c1 = c2 = 1.49618          # Balanced cognitive/social

Next Steps:

  • Apply theory in Tutorial 03: PSO Optimization

  • Tune controllers using Optimization API

  • Deep dive into PSO Mathematical Theory

Further Reading:

  • Kennedy, J., & Eberhart, R. (1995). Particle swarm optimization. Proc. IEEE ICNN.

  • Clerc, M., & Kennedy, J. (2002). The particle swarm-explosion, stability, and convergence in a multidimensional complex space. IEEE Trans. Evol. Comput.

  • Poli, R., et al. (2007). Particle swarm optimization: An overview. Swarm Intelligence.
